msContents.summary: This nearly complete copy Dābistān-i Maẕāhib (School of Religions) recounts various religious creeds and philosophical systems of Asia, as known to the author, divided into twelve ta‘līm (teachings) and subdivided into a various number of naẓar (observations). The author, whose name appears here as Mīr Ẕū al-Fiqār ‘Alī al-Ḥusaynī (ca. 1615–70), apparently followed the Āẕar Kayvānī illuminationist sect in India during the reign of the Mughal ruler ‘Ālamgīr I (r. 1658–1707). The author not only travelled throughout the northern Indian subcontinent, but also to Mashhad in Iran. As a result, he became thoroughly acquainted with a great number of religious and scientific Parsi, Hindu, Buddhist, Jewish, Christian, and Muslim personalities and their doctrines. . completed by Kāshī Nath a Brahmin from city of Sialkot, Punjab on the 15 Ramaz̤ān 1210 AH (24 Mar. 1796 CE).

msItem.incipit: برگ ۱ر (folio 1a): ای نام تو سر دفتر اطفال دبستان * یاد ببالغ نظران شمع شبستان.
msItem.explicit: برگ ٢٨٢ر (folio 282a): غرض نقشی‌ست کز ما ياد ماند * که هستی را نمی بینم بقائی.
msItem.colophon: برگ ٢٨٢ر (folio 282a): تم تم تمام شد صورت اختسام یافت. نسخه دبستان مذاهب بخط بنده کاشی ناتهه (؟) قوم بر همن متوطن ملک پنجاب بلده سیالکوت تحریر پذیرفت پانزدهم شهر رمضان المبارک سنهتم. ۱۲۱۰ هجری .
Completed by Kāshī Nath, a Brahmin from city of Sialkot, Punjab on 15 Ramaz̤ān 1210 AH (24 Mar. 1796 CE).
msItem.note:
A note on the margins of folio:
محسن فانی گوید...
(Muḥsin Fānī says...) refers to authorship of those verses, not the entire work. Former owner Samuel Hawtayne Lewin, cites an addendum by Sir W. Ouseley (Travels, Vol. III, p. 564) who attributes the work to Mūbad Shāh and identifies Muhsin Fani as only the poet quoted at the beginning, on the basis of this manuscript, then in the possession of former owner Sir Graves Champney Haughton, and still accepted by most current scholars. For other copies of this work, see Rylands Persian MS 75 and 190. Regarding the attribution of authorship for this work to Mīr Ẕū al-Fiqār ‘Alī al-Ḥusaynī Ardistānī, see Mojtabāʾī and Barzegar.

supportDesc.support: Primarily medium-weight, ivory-coloured, cross-grained, externally sized and polished paper, probably handmade in the Indian subcontinent with 8 laid lines per cm and few discernible chain lines. Folios 192–193 of comparatively thin, ivory-coloured, cross-grained paper, also probably handmade in the Indian subcontinent, with ~10 laid lines per cm and few discernible chain lines, added to replace missing folios.
supportDesc.foliation: Partially foliated in minute red Hindu-Arabic numerals on the upper-left corners of the a sides, from folios 1a to 183a.
Foliated in pencilled Arabic numeral on the upper-left corcers of the a sides from folios 184a to 286a.
supportDesc.collation: Undetermined due to tight, recessed resewing. Catchwords on the lower-left corners of the b sides throughout..
supportDesc.condition: Handle text with caution. Extensive insect damage throughout.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 1 column with 19 lines per page. Ruled with a misṭarah hand guide. Folio 192b left blank, while folio 182b features blank spaces intended for copying Arabic passages, but left incomplete.

handDesc.handNote: Copied in stylized black nasta‘līq with shikastah ligatures by Kāshī Nath.
Replaced folios 192–193 copied in a hasty black naskh by another hand to relace missing text.

binding.p: Probably rebound in a hybrid British-Indian style in the Bombay Presidency for former owner Jonathan Duncan (1756–1811) as the style comports with others that he formerly owned.

Resewn on five recessed cord supports, probably frayed out and put down under the lifted doublures. Covered in full maroon goatskin leather over pasteboards, tightbacked, with defined joints, sqaures along the edges, but without a flap (Type III binding per Déroche). Spine bears three raised bands.
binding.decoNote: Boards decorated with recessed paper onlays for the central scalloped mandorlas, detached pendants, and cornerpieces. Board margins stained black. Thin single-rule lines connect the central decoration, with thin double lines connecting the corners, and thick and thin lines surrounding the perimeters of the boards, all in yellow.
binding.condition: Binding in good condition. White salts on the exterior, likely due to prolonged exposure to moisture. Opening to the gutter margins restricted.

history.origin: Completed by Kāshī Nath, possibly in Sialkot, Punjab 15 Ramaz̤ān 1210 AH (24 Mar. 1796 CE).

provenance.p: Acquired in the Indian subcontinent by Jonathan Duncan (1756–1811), who governed the Bombay Presidency for 16 years from 1795 until his death.

After Duncan's death, his family sold his library through the London firm of Samuel Leigh Sotheby (1805–1861) where Sir Graves Champney Haughton (1788–1849), an early student at Fort William College who excelled in the study of several oriental languages and later professor of East India College at Haileybury, purchased for £12, as per his unsigned inscription on folio 1a.
Later acquired by Samuel Hawtayne Lewin (1795–1840), as per his signed inscription above an dbelow Haughton's on 1a.

Subsequently obtained by scholar Nathaniel Bland (1803–1865), after whose death, London bookseller Bernard Quaritch (1819–1899) sold his oriental manuscripts in 1866 to Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880).
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to the John Rylands Library.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993, derived from a manuscript handlist by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s and his Bibliotheca Lindesiana, Hand-list of Oriental Manuscripts: Arabic, Persian, Turkish, 1898.
Manuscript description by Jake Benson in 2022 with reference to the volume in hand.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.
